subject: Re: [junit] @AfterClass is poorly defined
msgSnippet: It makes sense to use BeforeClass and AfterClass in integration tests when you need to initialize expensive resources such the spring context, hibernate
messageBody:
It makes sense to use BeforeClass and AfterClass in integration tests
when you need to initialize expensive resources such the spring
context, hibernate sessionfactory, configuration etc. In BeforeClass
create the environment needed for such integration tests to run and
do your cleanup in AfterClass.


On Thu, Mar 5, 2009 at 2:25 AM, J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains762@...> wrote:
> On 2009-03-03, at 05:00 , kot_10_4 wrote:
>> It would be way more useful if this annotation could be applied to a
>> non-static method. The same could be said for @BeforeClass but at
>> least you can put code you would have put in @BeforeClass in the
>> constructor.
>>
> It would also violate the basics of good design and test isolation. I
> would never want something shared across multiple objects that was
> instance-level; that would confuse the hell out of me.
